bioghist.p: A pioneering neuroscientist, Sanford L. Palay (1918-2002) began research into the structure and function of the brain as a student at Western Reserve Medical School, where he received his MD in 1943. His research on the fine structure of synaptic vesicles at the Rockefeller Institute in 1953 resulted in a series of electron micrographs that are often cited as the first images of the synapse and of the structures that release messenger chemicals in the brain. His later work at the National Institutes of Health and at Harvard Medical School (1961-1989) helped provide a well-rounded picture of the structure of neuroglia (cells that support and protect neurons) and of the cerebellum. In 1980, Palay become the Editor-in-Chief of the Journal of Comparative Neurology, a position he held for fourteen years. After his retirement from Harvard, Palay accepted a position as Distinguished Scholar-in-Residence in the Department of Biology at Boston College.

scopecontent.p: The Palay collection contains the bulk of Palay's professional correspondence from his days as a medical student until after his retirement. The collection also contains some personal correspondence. Other materials include: Palay's course notes, papers, and laboratory notes from his undergraduate and graduate work; college yearbooks; diaries and calendars; drafts and proofs of papers and books, including Cerebellar Cortex, The Fine Structure of the Nervous System, and Coexistence of Neuroactive Substances in Neurons; a three-volume collection of Palay's articles; research notes on brain anatomy and physiology and on the golgi apparatus; lecture notes, examination questions, and handouts from courses Palay taught at Harvard and Yale; audio and video recordings of some of Palay's lectures; student records, including grade sheets; correspondence and recommendation letters for postdoctoral fellows; and a large number of electron micrographs of brain structures. The collection also includes editorial files from Palay's tenure as the editor of the Journal of Comparative Neurology (1980-1997). These files consist of correspondence with authors, reviewers, and publishers; reviewer and editorial comments; and reprints and offprints of articles from other publications.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
